line: TABLE OF CONTENTS
label: heading

line: HOW CAN I VOICE
label: heading

line: MY OPI NION?
label: paragraph

line: At each ICANN meeting,
label: paragraph

line: anyone can make comments
label: paragraph

line: and ask questions on the main
label: paragraph

line: topics directly to the Board at
label: paragraph

line: the Public Forum. During the
label: paragraph

line: Public Forum, you may speak
label: paragraph

line: on behalf of your organization
label: paragraph

line: or as an individual.
label: paragraph

line: The Public Forum usually lasts
label: paragraph

line: several hours on Thursday after-
label: paragraph

line: noon of every ICANN meeting.
label: paragraph

line: Commenters line up behind a
label: paragraph

line: microphone that is placed near
label: paragraph

line: the front of the room to ask a
label: paragraph

line: question or make a comment.
label: paragraph

line: Attendees are encouraged to
label: paragraph

line: be brief and concise to enable
label: paragraph

line: as many perspectives to be
label: paragraph

line: heard as possible. You don’t
label: paragraph

line: have to be physically present
label: paragraph

line: to participate – you can follow
label: paragraph

line: along online via ICANN’s Re-
label: paragraph

line: mote Participation services and
label: paragraph

line: submit questions or comments
label: paragraph

line: to be read out in the meeting
label: paragraph

line: room by a staff member.
label: paragraph

line: You can also provide feedback
label: paragraph

line: through public comment
label: paragraph

line: periods. See page 4.
label: paragraph

line: What is ICANN?
label: heading

line: ICANN is a not-for-profit, public-benefit organization formed in 1998. Its staff operates the Internet’s
label: paragraph

line: Domain Name System, coordinates allocation and assignment of the Internet’s unique identifiers,
label: paragraph

line: such as Internet Protocol addresses, accredits generic top-level domain (gTLD) name registrars, and
label: paragraph

line: helps facilitate the voices of volunteers worldwide who are dedicated to keeping the Internet secure,
label: paragraph

line: stable and interoperable. ICANN promotes competition in the domain name space and helps develop
label: paragraph

line: Internet policy.
label: paragraph

line: How is ICANN organized?
label: heading

line: At the heart of ICANN’s policy-making is what is called a “multistakeholder model.” This decentralized
label: paragraph

line: governance model places individuals, industry, non-commercial interests and government on an equal
label: paragraph

line: level. Unlike more traditional, top-down governance models, where governments make policy deci-
label: paragraph

line: sions, the multistakeholder approach used by ICANN allows for community-based consensus-driven
label: paragraph

line: policy-making. The idea is that Internet governance should mimic the structure of the Internet itself
label: paragraph

line: borderless and open to all.
label: paragraph

line: While the ICANN Board of Directors has the ultimate authority to approve or reject policy recommenda-
label: paragraph

line: tions, Supporting Organizations (SOs) are responsible for developing and making policy recommenda-
label: paragraph

line: tions to the Board. Advisory Committees (ACs) advise the ICANN Board and, in certain cases, can raise
label: paragraph

line: issues for policy development. The SO/ACs are described in more detail later in this booklet.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN staff is responsible for executing and implementing policies developed by the ICANN community
label: paragraph

line: and adopted by the ICANN Board.
label: paragraph

line: The ICANN Ombudsman is an independent, impartial and neutral person contracted to ICANN, with ju-
label: paragraph

line: risdiction over problems and complaints made about decisions, actions or inactions by ICANN, the Board
label: paragraph

line: of Directors, or unfair treatment of a community member by ICANN staff, Board or a constituency body.
label: paragraph

line: The Nominating Committee is a team of community volunteers responsible for the selection of eight
label: paragraph

line: ICANN Board members, and portions of the At-Large Advisory Committee, the Country Code Names
label: paragraph

line: Supporting Organization and the Generic Names Supporting Organization.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN
label: paragraph

line: Multistakeholder
label: paragraph

line: Model
label: paragraph

line: What Happens at an ICANN Meeting?
label: heading

line: ICANN holds three international public meetings each calendar year in different regions of the globe.
label: paragraph

line: One meeting each year is also the organization’s annual general meeting, during which new Board
label: paragraph

line: members take their seats.
label: paragraph

line: Usually comprised of more than 200 different sessions, the week-long meeting is a focal point for
label: paragraph

line: individuals and representatives of the different ICANN stakeholders (either attending in-person or
label: paragraph

line: participating remotely) to introduce and discuss issues related to ICANN policy. In most cases anyone
label: paragraph

line: may speak, but in a few cases you may need to be a member of a particular group. If you are uncertain
label: paragraph

line: of the rules during a session, simply ask the session leader if you may speak.
label: paragraph

line: Meetings are open to everyone and registration is free, but you are responsible for your own travel
label: paragraph

line: and lodging. ICANN offers limited financial assistance to members of its Supporting Organizations and
label: paragraph

line: Advisory Committees. Also, there is a Fellowship program for selected candidates from developing
label: paragraph

line: countries who otherwise could not afford to attend in-person.
label: paragraph

line: If you cannot physically attend a meeting, ICANN offers a variety of services to ensure that the power of
label: paragraph

line: participation is just a click away. Virtual meeting rooms are available for nearly all sessions with access
label: paragraph

line: to meeting materials, a chat room and for larger or general sessions, video and/or audio streaming
label: paragraph

line: and live transcription.
label: paragraph

line: Learn more at http://meetings.icann.org/remote-participation.
label: paragraph

line: Though English is the main language at ICANN meetings, translation, scribing and interpretation are
label: paragraph

line: available at certain sessions. Many documents are made available in Arabic, Chinese, French, Russian
label: paragraph

line: and Spanish.
label: paragraph

line: Each meeting has a dedicated web site with a frequently updated meeting schedule, venue map,
label: paragraph

line: information on the local area and social events.
label: paragraph

line: Newcomers’ Program at ICANN Meetings
label: heading

line: ICANN welcomes Newcomers into its multistakeholder process through a special orientation program
label: paragraph

line: during its meetings. First launched at ICANN 40 in March 2011, the Newcomers’ Program is a starting
label: paragraph

line: point for understanding ICANN and its community, what it does and how the system works. It also
label: paragraph

line: helps Newcomers engage with the ICANN community and participate effectively so that they leave
label: paragraph

line: the meeting well informed and willing to come back.
label: paragraph

line: Greeters at the Newcomers
label: paragraph

line: Lounge at ICANN meetings
label: paragraph

line: are ready to answer questions
label: paragraph

line: and introduce newcomers
label: paragraph

line: and Fellows to more seasoned
label: paragraph

line: community members.
label: paragraph

line: Newcomers' Sunday Track
label: heading

line: On the Sunday before the meeting begins, ICANN holds a series of training sessions – usually between
label: paragraph

line: 10:00 and 18:00 – just for Newcomers. Among the topics covered are an introduction to ICANN, how
label: paragraph

line: to use ICANN engagement tools, how the community interacts during and in between meetings, and
label: paragraph

line: much more. Participation and Engagement staff coordinate these sessions, and various ICANN staff
label: paragraph

line: conduct them, depending on the expertise subject matter.
label: paragraph

line: Newcomers' Lounge
label: heading

line: First-time attendees can relax, get information and interact with staff and Fellowship Program alumni
label: paragraph

line: volunteers at the Newcomers’ Lounge. Helping to alleviate any first-time meeting anxiety, these mentors
label: paragraph

line: provide hands-on support, guidance and introductions to community members, the ICANN structure
label: paragraph

line: and process, and advice on sessions of interest. The Lounge is open from Saturday to Wednesday dur-
label: paragraph

line: ing ICANN meetings.
label: paragraph

line: Public Comment Periods at ICANN
label: heading

line: A vital element in ICANN's processes is the opportunity for public comment on each substantial piece
label: paragraph

line: of work before it is considered for approval. These topics can be operational (such as budget or stra-
label: paragraph

line: tegic planning), technical (such as security reports and recommendations) or policy-oriented (such as
label: paragraph

line: Bylaw changes).
label: paragraph

line: The following principles guide the public comment process:
label: paragraph

line: Each session offers
label: paragraph

line: remote participation ■■ Each item posted for public comment is available for a
label: paragraph

line: minimum of 21 days.
label: paragraph

line: options for either low- or
label: paragraph

line: If comments are received, then at the close of the
label: paragraph

line: high-bandwidth users. comment period, a reply period begins, lasting a
label: paragraph

line: minimum of 21 days.
label: paragraph

line: ■■ If no substantive comments are received during the
label: paragraph

line: comment period, then there will be no reply period.
label: paragraph

line: ■■ During the reply period, participants should address
label: paragraph

line: previous comments submitted; new posts concerning the
label: paragraph

line: topic should not be introduced. When constructing replies,
label: paragraph

line: contributors are asked to cite the original poster’s name,
label: paragraph

line: comment date, and any particular text that is pertinent.
label: paragraph

line: You can find a list of all topics open for public comment on a dedicated public comment page (http://
label: paragraph

line: www.icann.org/en/news/public-comment). The page includes links to relevant announcements, docu-
label: paragraph

line: ments, comment locations, and reference sources with full descriptions and background information.
label: paragraph

line: After the comment period is closed, staff publishes a comment summary report that is archived along
label: paragraph

line: with all public comment documentation and comments received.
label: paragraph

line: The Fellowship Program provides
label: paragraph

line: grants to members of the global
label: paragraph

line: Internet community who would
label: paragraph

line: otherwise be unable to attend.
label: paragraph

line: Fellows come from ccTLDs,
label: paragraph

line: governments, civil society,
label: paragraph

line: the business community and
label: paragraph

line: academia. Learn more at http://
label: paragraph

line: www.icann.org/en/about/
label: paragraph

line: participate/fellowships.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN Board of Directors
label: heading

line: An internationally diverse Board of Directors oversees the policy development process and ICANN
label: paragraph

line: governance. The Board has 16 voting members and five non-voting liaison representatives. ICANN’s
label: paragraph

line: President serves as an ex oficio, voting member of the Board.
label: paragraph

line: The Address Supporting Organization (ASO), the Country Code Names Supporting Organization (ccNSO)
label: paragraph

line: and the Generic Names Supporting Organization (GNSO) each select two voting members of the Board.
label: paragraph

line: The At-Large Advisory Committee (ALAC) in conjunction with the Regional At-Large Organizations (RALOS)
label: paragraph

line: selects one voting member. A Nominating Committee selects the remaining eight voting members.
label: paragraph

line: Non-voting liaisons to the Board provide technical advice to inform Board decision-making. ICANN’s
label: paragraph

line: Governmental Advisory Committee (GAC), Root Server System Advisory Committee (RSSAC) and Security
label: paragraph

line: & Stability Advisory Committee (SSAC) each appoint a Board liaison. ICANN’s Technical Liaison Group
label: paragraph

line: appoints a liaison to the Board, as does the Internet Engineering Task Force, which is an international
label: paragraph

line: and decentralized organization that develops and designs standards for the Internet system.
label: paragraph

line: SUP PO RT IN G O RGAN IZAT ION S
label: paragraph

line: ICANN has three Supporting Organizations that develop and recommend policies concerning the
label: paragraph

line: Internet’s technical management within their areas of expertise.
label: paragraph

line: They are the Address Supporting Organization (ASO), the Country Code Names Supporting Organiza-
label: paragraph

line: tion (ccNSO) and the Generic Names Supporting Organization (GNSO).
label: paragraph

line: Address Supporting Organization
label: heading

line: What is the Address Supporting Organization?
label: heading

line: An advisory body to the ICANN Board on global policy issues relating to the operation, allocation and
label: paragraph

line: management of Internet Protocol addresses, the Address Supporting Organization (ASO) is comprised
label: paragraph

line: of representatives of five autonomous Regional Internet Registries (RIRs). These RIRs manage regional
label: paragraph

line: distribution of Internet number resources including IP address and Autonomous System Numbers.
label: paragraph

line: Each RIR is a member of the Number Resource Organization, which coordinates their activities globally.
label: paragraph

line: The five RIRs are:
label: heading

line: ■■ African Network Information Center (AfriNIC), covering ■■ Latin American and Caribbean Internet Addresses Regis-
label: paragraph

line: the African continent
label: paragraph

line: try (LACNIC), covering Latin America and Caribbean
label: paragraph

line: ■■ Asia Pacific Network Information Centre (APNIC), ■■ Réseaux IP Européens (RIPE NCC), covering Europe, the
label: paragraph

line: covering the Asia-Pacific region including Japan, Middle East and parts of Asia
label: paragraph

line: ICANN’s Board of Directors,
label: paragraph

line: Korea, China, and Australia
label: paragraph

line: ■■ American Registry for Internet Numbers (ARIN),
label: paragraph

line: covering Canada, some Caribbean and North Atlantic
label: paragraph

line: islands and the United States
label: paragraph

line: What is the ASO Address Council?
label: heading

line: The Address Council is made up of the Address Supporting Organization and its purpose is to oversee
label: paragraph

line: recommendations to the ICANN Board of Directors on Internet Protocol address policy and to manage
label: paragraph

line: the global policy development activities. The Address Council is also responsible for appointing two
label: paragraph

line: voting members to the ICANN Board.
label: paragraph

line: How is the ASO Address Council chosen?
label: heading

line: Address Council members are appointed through separate nominations and election processes in
label: paragraph

line: each of the Regional Internet Registry regions. Each of the five Regional Internet Registries appoints
label: paragraph

line: three members of the ASO Address Council for two-year terms. The Council elects a chair who appoints
label: paragraph

line: vice-chairs.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved in the ASO?
label: heading

line: Most individuals get involved in the ASO through affiliation with a Regional Internet Registry. If your
label: paragraph

line: organization receives a direct allocation or holds a direct assignment of IPv4 or IPv6 addresses from a
label: paragraph

line: registry, you are likely already a member of that RIR. (Generally speaking, these are Internet Providers,
label: paragraph

line: hosting firms, educational institutions or governments.)
label: paragraph

line: photographed at ICANN 44
label: paragraph

line: in Prague.
label: paragraph

line: The ccNSO provides a forum
label: paragraph

line: for country code top-level
label: paragraph

line: domain managers to meet and
label: paragraph

line: discuss issues of concern from
label: paragraph

line: a global perspective.
label: paragraph

line: However, the RIRs have no membership requirements to participate in their policy development pro-
label: paragraph

line: cesses or attend their meetings. Anyone in the Internet community is welcome to participate in the
label: paragraph

line: development of Internet resource allocation polices for that region.
label: paragraph

line: Where can I find more information about the ASO or an RIR?
label: heading

line: Address Supporting Organization
label: heading

line: www.aso.icann.org
label: paragraph

line: African Network Information Center (AfriNIC) www.afrinic.net
label: paragraph

line: Asia Pacific Network Information Centre (APNIC) www.apnic.net
label: paragraph

line: American Registry for Internet Numbers (ARIN) www.arin.net
label: paragraph

line: Latin American and Caribbean Internet Addresses Registry (LACNIC) www.lacnic.net
label: paragraph

line: Réseaux IP Européens (RIPE NCC)
label: paragraph

line: www.ripe.net
label: paragraph

line: Country Code Names Supporting Organization
label: heading

line: What is the Country Code Names Supporting Organization (ccNSO)?
label: heading

line: The ccNSO is a Supporting Organization responsible for developing and recommending to ICANN’s
label: paragraph

line: Board global policies relating to country code top-level domains (ccTLDs). It also provides a platform
label: paragraph

line: to the ccTLD community to develop best practices, exchange information and discuss global issues
label: paragraph

line: relevant for ccTLDs. A ccTLD is a two-letter domain name extension corresponding to a country, territory
label: paragraph

line: or other geographic location, such as .uk (United Kingdom), .de (Germany) and .jp (Japan).
label: paragraph

line: What is the ccNSO Council?
label: heading

line: The ccNSO Council administers and coordinates the affairs of the ccNSO and manages the development
label: paragraph

line: of policy recommendations. They lead and participate in various ccNSO Working Groups and engage
label: paragraph

line: the community in topical issues. The Council formally selects two members to the ICANN Board, after
label: paragraph

line: being elected by the ccNSO Members.
label: paragraph

line: How is the ccNSO Council chosen?
label: heading

line: The ccNSO Council has 18 members serving staggered three-year terms. ccNSO members elect 15
label: paragraph

line: Councilors, three from each of the five geographic regions. ccNSO members may self-nominate or be
label: paragraph

line: nominated by another ccNSO member from their region; nominations must be seconded by another
label: paragraph

line: ccNSO member from the region. ICANN’s Nominating Committee fills the remaining three seats.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved in the ccNSO?
label: heading

line: If you are the manager of an International Standards Organization 3166 (ISO 3166) country code top-level
label: paragraph

line: domain, you are welcome to become a member of the ccNSO or to participate in any of its Working
label: paragraph

line: Groups and attend any of its meetings. The application to join is at http://ccnso.icann.org/applications/
label: paragraph

line: form.htm. There is no membership fee.
label: paragraph

line: Where can I find more information about the ccNSO?
label: heading

line: http://ccnso.icann.org/
label: paragraph

line: The Generic Names Supporting
label: paragraph

line: Organization Council at ICANN’s
label: paragraph

line: 44th Public Meeting in Prague.
label: paragraph

line: Generic Names Supporting Organization
label: heading

line: What is the Generic Names Supporting Organization?
label: heading

line: The Generic Names Supporting Organization (GNSO) is the policy-making body responsible for ge-
label: paragraph

line: neric top-level domains, such as .COM, .NET and .ORG. Its members include representatives from gTLD
label: paragraph

line: registries, gTLD registrars, intellectual property interests, Internet service providers, businesses and
label: paragraph

line: non-commercial interests.
label: paragraph

line: What are Stakeholder Groups within the GNSO?
label: heading

line: Stakeholder Groups function as caucuses, and are intended to facilitate the creation of the new con-
label: paragraph

line: stituencies as well as growth and expansion of GNSO participants. There are four Stakeholder Groups
label: paragraph

line: representing the wide variety of groups and individuals interested in generic top-level domain policy
label: paragraph

line: development. They are:
label: paragraph

line: ■■ Commercial Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: ■■ Non-commercial Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: What is the GNSO Council?
label: heading

line: ■■ Registrar Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: ■■ gTLD Registries Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: The 23 members of the Council govern policy development in the GNSO, make policy recommenda-
label: paragraph

line: tions to the ICANN Board and appoint two members to the ICANN Board.
label: paragraph

line: How are the members of the GNSO Council chosen?
label: heading

line: Stakeholder Groups appoint 18 of the GNSO Council’s 23 members. For voting purposes, the Council
label: paragraph

line: has two houses, like the US Congress or the British Parliament. The Contracted Parties House holds
label: paragraph

line: the Registries and Registrars Stakeholder Groups, while the Non-Contracted Parties House holds the
label: paragraph

line: Commercial and Non-Commercial Stakeholder Groups. ICANN’s Nominating Committee appoints three
label: paragraph

line: Council members, two of which are voting members assigned to each House. The third appointee is an
label: paragraph

line: advisor to the Council as a whole. The Council also includes formally appointed but non-voting Liaisons
label: paragraph

line: and Observers from other groups, such as the At-Large Community and the ccNSO, within ICANN. This
label: paragraph

line: elaborate system provides checks and balances so no single interest group can dominate the Council.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved in the GNSO?
label: heading

line: GNSO-chartered Working Groups are formally chartered within the ICANN Structure to address policies
label: paragraph

line: and other issues facing the Internet community and its stakeholders. In general, anyone can join these
label: paragraph

line: groups and they are typically made up of volunteers with various interests and expertise. One of many
label: paragraph

line: tools used by Working Groups are mailing lists that are publicly archived. Community members can
label: paragraph

line: follow email lists for the latest dialogue and deliberation of policy topics and activity.
label: paragraph

line: Monitor the ICANN.ORG home page for announcements about calls for volunteers to Working Groups,
label: paragraph

line: and when you see one you are interested in, send the GNSO Secretariat an email expressing your
label: paragraph

line: interest. You’ll be asked to draft a Statement of Interest so that other group members can learn more
label: paragraph

line: about you. And they’ll be asked to do the same. Working groups usually meet via weekly or bi-weekly
label: paragraph

line: conference calls, but each one establishes the best schedule for the group.
label: paragraph

line: You may also apply for membership in one of the GNSO’s Stakeholder Groups or Constituencies. Stake-
label: paragraph

line: holder Groups and Constituencies are groups of community participants united around a particular
label: paragraph

line: common interest or perspective, formally recognized by the ICANN Board. Each Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: and Constituency has its own unique eligibility rules. Also, membership fees may be required to join
label: paragraph

line: a Stakeholder Group or Constituency. For more information about specific membership requirements
label: paragraph

line: and joining, visit the web sites listed below.
label: paragraph

line: GNSO Stakeholder Groups and Constituencies
label: heading

line: Commercial Business Users Constituency
label: paragraph

line: http://www.bizconst.org/
label: paragraph

line: Intellectual Property Constituency
label: paragraph

line: http://www.ipconstituency.org/
label: paragraph

line: Internet Service Providers Constituency
label: paragraph

line: http://www.ispcp.info/
label: paragraph

line: Non-commercial Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: http://gnso.icann.org/en/non-commercial/
label: paragraph

line: Non-commercial Users Constituency
label: paragraph

line: http://ncuc.org/
label: paragraph

line: Not-for-Profit Operational Concerns Constituency
label: paragraph

line: http://www.npoc.org/home.html
label: paragraph

line: Registrar Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: http://www.icannregistrars.org/
label: paragraph

line: gTLD Registries Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: http://www.gtldregistries.org/
label: paragraph

line: ADVIS ORY C OMMITTEES
label: paragraph

line: ICANN has four Advisory Committees that serve as formal advisory bodies to the ICANN Board. They
label: paragraph

line: are made up of representatives from the Internet community to advise on a particular issue or policy
label: paragraph

line: area. ICANN Bylaws mandate four: At-Large Advisory Committee, DNS Root Server System Advisory
label: paragraph

line: Committee, Governmental Advisory Committee, and Security and Stability Advisory Committee.
label: paragraph

line: At-Large Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: What is the At-Large Advisory Committee?
label: heading

line: The At-Large Advisory Committee (ALAC) is the primary organizational home for the voice and con-
label: paragraph

line: cerns of the individual Internet user in ICANN processes. Its role is to consider and provide advice on
label: paragraph

line: the activities of ICANN insofar as they relate to the interests of individual Internet users. This includes
label: paragraph

line: policies created through ICANN’s Supporting Organizations, as well as the many other issues for which
label: paragraph

line: community input and advice is appropriate. The ALAC and At-Large Community selects one member
label: paragraph

line: of the ICANN Board of Directors.
label: paragraph

line: ALAC is a subset of the “At-Large Community” which has a ground-up, tiered structure. At the grassroots
label: paragraph

line: level are nearly 150 At-Large Structures (ALSes). These local organizations of At-Large members are
label: paragraph

line: located throughout the world. The ALSes are organized by region through five Regional At-Large Or-
label: paragraph

line: ganizations, or RALOs. The RALOs are the main forum and coordination point for their part of the world.
label: paragraph

line: Joining a constituency or a
label: paragraph

line: stakeholder group is the most
label: paragraph

line: common way to get involved
label: paragraph

line: in the GNSO.
label: paragraph

line: Following are the five RALOs:
label: heading

line: ■■ African Regional At-Large Organization (AFRALO)
label: paragraph

line: http://www.atlarge.icann.org/afralo/
label: paragraph

line: ■■ Asia Pacific Regional At-Large Organization (APRALO)
label: paragraph

line: http://www.atlarge.icann.org/apralo/
label: paragraph

line: ■■ European At-Large Organization (EURALO)
label: paragraph

line: http://www.atlarge.icann.org/euralo/
label: paragraph

line: ICANN At-Large Organization Diagram
label: paragraph

line: ■■ Latin American and Caribbean Islands Regional At-Large
label: paragraph

line: Organization (LACRALO)
label: paragraph

line: http://www.atlarge.icann.org/lacralo/
label: paragraph

line: ■■ North American Regional At-Large Organization (NARALO)
label: paragraph

line: http://www.atlarge.icann.org/naralo/
label: paragraph

line: 2012 marked the ten-year anniversary of the At-Large Advisory Committee in its current form. The ALAC was created
label: paragraph

line: to provide a way for active individual users of the Internet from around the world to participate in ICANN.
label: paragraph

line: How are the members of ALAC chosen?
label: heading

line: The 15-member ALAC consists of two members selected by each of the Regional At-Large Organiza-
label: paragraph

line: tions for a total of ten directly appointed representatives, and five members selected by the Nominating
label: paragraph

line: Committee. The five members selected by the Nominating Committee shall include one citizen of a
label: paragraph

line: country within each of the five Geographic Regions.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved with ALAC?
label: heading

line: An individual Internet user typically joins At-Large by joining one of its local ALSes, and then through
label: paragraph

line: the ALS becomes involved in their RALO.
label: paragraph

line: However, an individual Internet user may also be able to join a RALO directly. The RALOs are tasked with
label: paragraph

line: keeping the Internet user community in their region informed about ICANN’s activities through public
label: paragraph

line: outreach and distribution of information and knowledge. Each RALO is autonomous, governed by its
label: paragraph

line: own organizing documents. While each RALO elects a chair and secretariat, and in some cases a vice
label: paragraph

line: president, they have their own requirements for the positions.
label: paragraph

line: Since all At-Large meetings are open, individual members may participate in At-Large community
label: paragraph

line: meetings, or the conference calls of ALAC, RALOs, subcommittees and Working Groups.
label: paragraph

line: How does ALAC get involved in ICANN’s policy-making process?
label: heading

line: In cases in which the ALAC has determined that an emerging ICANN policy is of significant importance
label: paragraph

line: to individual Internet users, it gets involved early in the policy development process, often enlisting
label: paragraph

line: At-Large members to directly participate in the Working Group developing the policy. ALAC may also
label: paragraph

line: submit a Public Comment describing its position.
label: paragraph

line: There are Working Groups within the At-Large Community, as well as WGs that consist of members
label: paragraph

line: from different Supporting Organizations and Advisory Committees. The ALAC has established a number
label: paragraph

line: of standing WGs and subcommittees to work on ongoing or long-term issues. Learn more at https://
label: paragraph

line: community.icann.org/display/atlarge/At-Large+Working+Groups.
label: paragraph

line: How can I find more information about ALAC and the At-Large Community?
label: heading

line: The At-Large home page at www.atlarge.icann.org is the main starting point for news and reference
label: paragraph

line: documents about the At-Large Community. The At-Large community wiki page is also an excellent
label: paragraph

line: source of information on At-Large activities (see: https://community.icann.org/display/atlarge/At-
label: paragraph

line: Large+Advisory+Committee+%28ALAC%29).
label: paragraph

line: Governmental Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: What is the Governmental Advisory Committee?
label: heading

line: The Governmental Advisory Committee is comprised of appointed representatives of national govern-
label: paragraph

line: ments, multi-national governmental organizations and treaty organizations, and distinct economies.
label: paragraph

line: How does the GAC participate in the ICANN policy-making process?
label: heading

line: The GAC’s key role is to provide advice to ICANN on issues of public policy, especially where there may
label: paragraph

line: be an interaction between ICANN’s activities or policies and national laws or international agreements.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN duly takes into account the GAC’s advice on public policy matters, both in the formulation and
label: paragraph

line: adoption of policies.
label: paragraph

line: The GAC usually meets three times a year in conjunction with ICANN meetings, where it discusses
label: paragraph

line: issues with the ICANN Board and other ICANN Supporting Organizations, Advisory Committees and
label: paragraph

line: other groups.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved with the GAC?
label: heading

line: According to its operating principles, “national governments or distinct economies as recognized in
label: paragraph

line: international fora” may be GAC members.
label: paragraph

line: Governments and others interested in joining the GAC as a member or observer can send a formal
label: paragraph

line: enquiry to the GAC Secretariat.
label: paragraph

line: GAC meetings are typically
label: paragraph

line: attended by approximately
label: paragraph

line: 50 national governments,
label: paragraph

line: distinct economies, and global
label: paragraph

line: organizations such as the ITU,
label: paragraph

line: UNESCO, the World Intellectual
label: paragraph

line: Property Organization
label: paragraph

line: (WIPO), INTERPOL and regional
label: paragraph

line: organizations such as the
label: paragraph

line: OECD, Asia Pacific Forum, and
label: paragraph

line: Council of Europe.
label: paragraph

line: How is an individual chosen to participate in the GAC on behalf of a member or observer
label: heading

line: organization?
label: heading

line: Each GAC member or observer may appoint one representative and one alternate to the GAC. Advisors
label: paragraph

line: may accompany the accredited representative. The accredited representative, alternate and advisors
label: paragraph

line: must hold a formal official position with the GAC member’s public administration. GAC members elect
label: paragraph

line: a chair who serves as a non-voting liaison to the ICANN Board.
label: paragraph

line: How does the GAC make decisions?
label: heading

line: The GAC works on the basis of seeking consensus among its membership. Consistent with United Nations
label: paragraph

line: practice, consensus is understood to mean the practice of adopting decisions by general agreement
label: paragraph

line: in the absence of any formal objection. Where consensus is not possible, the Chair shall convey the full
label: paragraph

line: range of views expressed by members to the ICANN Board.
label: paragraph

line: Where can I find more information about the GAC?
label: heading

line: The GAC has a web site where it posts general information, meeting materials, presentations and vari-
label: paragraph

line: ous types of papers distributed at its meetings. In addition, at the end of every ICANN Public Meeting
label: paragraph

line: where the GAC meets, the GAC issues a formal communiqué that provides comment on the issues it
label: paragraph

line: discussed. Transcripts of open sessions are released a few weeks after the meetings.
label: paragraph

line: Root Server System Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: What is the Root Server System Advisory Committee?
label: heading

line: The RSSAC is an advisory committee to the ICANN Board about the operation of the root name servers
label: paragraph

line: of the Domain Name System, including the operational requirements of root name servers, such as
label: paragraph

line: host hardware capacities, operating systems and name server software versions, network connectivity
label: paragraph

line: and physical environment.
label: paragraph

line: How are members of the RSSAC chosen?
label: heading

line: RSSAC members are representatives of organizations responsible for operating the world’s thirteen root
label: paragraph

line: name servers and other organizations concerned with stable technical operation of the authoritative
label: paragraph

line: root server system.
label: paragraph

line: How does RSSAC get involved in ICANN’s policy-making process?
label: heading

line: RSSAC responds to requests from ICANN’s Board of Directors for advice on technical issues. They de-
label: paragraph

line: velop consensus-based advice on issues such as the deployment of internationalized domain names
label: paragraph

line: in the root zone.
label: paragraph

line: How can I get involved in RSSAC?
label: heading

line: The RSSAC typically holds its meetings during those of the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF) rather
label: paragraph

line: than during ICANN meetings. These often occur a few weeks after an ICANN meeting in a different
label: paragraph

line: location.
label: paragraph

line: Where can I find more information about RSSAC?
label: heading

line: RSSAC advice and other information can be found at http://www.icann.org/en/groups/rssac.
label: paragraph

line: Security and Stability Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: What is the Security and Stability Advisory Committee?
label: heading

line: The SSAC is an advisory committee to the ICANN Board and community, comprised of technical experts
label: paragraph

line: from industry and academia as well as operators of Internet root servers, registrars and TLD registries.
label: paragraph

line: Its activities relate to the security and integrity of the Internet’s naming and address allocation systems.
label: paragraph

line: How are members of the SSAC chosen?
label: heading

line: The ICANN Board appoints the chair and members of SSAC. The SSAC Membership Committee meets
label: paragraph

line: with potential candidates and reviews their experience, interest, and skills before making recommenda-
label: paragraph

line: tions for membership to the SSAC. If the SSAC agrees to admit new members based on those recom-
label: paragraph

line: mendations it then requests Board appointments via the SSAC Liaison to the Board.
label: paragraph

line: The Brussels (pictured left)
label: paragraph

line: and Los Angeles offices are two
label: paragraph

line: of four new ICANN facilities
label: paragraph

line: opened in the past two years to
label: paragraph

line: accommodate an increasing staff
label: paragraph

line: size and enhanced security and
label: paragraph

line: technology features. The offices
label: paragraph

line: in Silicon Valley and Washington
label: paragraph

line: D.C. opened in 2010.
label: paragraph

line: Launched in October 2012, MyICANN is an information
label: paragraph

line: portal offering personal delivery of topical and timely
label: paragraph

line: information from all over the ICANN community.
label: paragraph

label: heading

line: DNS
label: paragraph

line: DNSO

line: DNSSEC
label: paragraph

line: DOMAIN
label: paragraph

line: EURALO

label: heading

line: FoI
label: paragraph

line: Domain Name System
label: paragraph

line: A system that allows Internet users to type in names, like www.inter-
label: paragraph

line: nic.net, and be directed to a machine-understandable unique Internet
label: paragraph

line: Protocol address like 207.151.159.3. Sometimes compared to a phone
label: paragraph

line: directory for the Internet.
label: paragraph

line: Domain Name Supporting Organization
label: paragraph

line: From 1999 to 2002, the ICANN Supporting Organization representing
label: paragraph

line: participants in the operation and use of the Domain Name System.
label: paragraph

line: Dissolved and replaced by the Generic Names Supporting Organiza-
label: paragraph

line: tion and the Country-Code Names Supporting Organization in 2003.
label: paragraph

line: Domain Name System Security Extensions
label: paragraph

line: DNSSEC introduces security at the infrastructure level through a
label: paragraph

line: hierarchy of cryptographic signatures attached to the DNS records.
label: paragraph

line: Users are assured that the source of the data is verifiably the stated
label: paragraph

line: source, and that the mapping of name to Internet Protocol (IP) address
label: paragraph

line: is accurate. DNSSEC-compliant name servers also provide denial of
label: paragraph

line: existence, that is, they tell a user that a name does not exist. There are
label: paragraph

line: two dominant strategies: (1) a process that zone operators can initiate
label: paragraph

line: for digitally signing their own zones by employing public-private key
label: paragraph

line: pairs and (2) a chain of trust between parent and child that enables
label: paragraph

line: the system eventually to become trustworthy.
label: paragraph

line: Computers throughout the world that respond to an Internet user’s
label: paragraph

line: request to resolve a domain name - for example when the user types
label: paragraph

line: in a name like internic.net in order to find the corresponding Internet
label: paragraph

line: Protocol address (207.151.159.3).
label: paragraph

line: Dispute Resolution Procedure
label: paragraph

line: A formal mechanism for solving disagreements or conflicts between
label: paragraph

line: parties.
label: paragraph

line: European Regional At-Large Organization
label: paragraph

line: One of the five Regional At-Large Organizations that together form
label: paragraph

line: the At-Large Community within ICANN. It provides news, resources,
label: paragraph

line: and information for individuals and end-user groups in the European
label: paragraph

line: region.
label: paragraph

line: Framework of Interpretation Working Group
label: paragraph

line: A group of ICANN community members responsible for creating a
label: paragraph

line: clear guide for the delegation and redelegation of ccTLDs, in order to
label: paragraph

line: ensure consistent and predictable decision-making.
label: paragraph

line: G
label: heading

line: Governmental Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: GAC
label: heading

line: An advisory committee to the ICANN Board, comprising appointed
label: paragraph

line: representatives of national governments, multi-national governmental
label: paragraph

line: organizations and treaty organizations, and distinct economies.
label: paragraph

line: Generic Top Level Domain
label: paragraph

line: GTLD
label: paragraph

line: Internet domain name extensions of three letters or more, such as
label: paragraph

line: .COM, .NET and .ASIA.
label: paragraph

line: Generic Names Supporting Organization
label: heading

line: GNSO
label: heading

line: The main policy-making body within ICANN responsible for generic
label: paragraph

line: top-level domains. Its members include representatives from gTLD
label: paragraph

line: registries, ICANN-accredited registrars, intellectual property interests,
label: paragraph

line: Internet service providers, businesses and non-commercial interests.
label: paragraph

line: H
label: heading

line: High Security Top-Level Domain
label: paragraph

line: HSTLD
label: paragraph

line: A standard developed by ICANN’s Security and Stability Advisory Com-
label: paragraph

line: mittee and made optional for new gTLD operators who want to be
label: paragraph

line: known as a secure, trustworthy domain.
label: paragraph

line: I
label: heading

line: Internet Architecture Board
label: paragraph

line: IAB
label: paragraph

line: A committee of the Internet Society, responsible for oversight of the
label: paragraph

line: technical and engineering development of the Internet. It oversees a
label: paragraph

line: number of task forces including the Internet Engineering Task Force.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Assigned Numbers Authority
label: paragraph

line: IANA
label: paragraph

line: The authority originally responsible for the oversight of IP address
label: paragraph

line: allocation, the coordination of the assignment of protocol parameters
label: paragraph

line: provided for within Internet technical standards, and the management
label: paragraph

line: of the Domain Name System, including the delegation of top-level
label: paragraph

line: domains and oversight of the root name server system.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers
label: paragraph

line: ICANN
label: heading

line: An internationally organized, non-profit corporation with responsibility
label: paragraph

line: for Internet Protocol address space allocation, protocol identifier as-
label: paragraph

line: signment, generic and country code top-level Domain Name System
label: paragraph

line: management, and root server system management functions.
label: paragraph

line: Internationalized Domain Names
label: paragraph

line: IDNS
label: paragraph

line: Domain names that include characters used in the local representa-
label: paragraph

line: tion of languages that are not written with the twenty-six letters of the
label: paragraph

line: basic Latin alphabet “a-z”. An IDN can contain Latin letters with diacriti-
label: paragraph

line: cal marks, as required by many European languages, or may consist of
label: paragraph

line: characters from non-Latin scripts such as Arabic or Chinese.
label: paragraph

line: IETF
label: paragraph

line: INTA

line: Internet Engineering Task Force
label: paragraph

line: An open international community of network designers, operators,
label: paragraph

line: vendors, and researchers concerned with the evolution of the Internet
label: paragraph

line: architecture and the smooth operation of the Internet.
label: paragraph

line: International Trademark Association
label: paragraph

line: A not-for-profit membership association dedicated to the support and
label: paragraph

line: advancement of trademarks and related intellectual property as ele-
label: paragraph

line: ments of fair and effective commerce.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Protocol
label: paragraph

line: The standard procedures and formats that govern how computers
label: paragraph

line: communicate with each other over the Internet using unique ad-
label: paragraph

line: dresses.
label: paragraph

line: Intellectual Property Constituency
label: paragraph

line: A constituency of the Generic Names Supporting Organization
label: paragraph

line: charged with the responsibility of advising the ICANN Board on policy
label: paragraph

line: issues relating to the management of the Domain Name System.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Protocol version 4
label: paragraph

line: The original Internet Protocol, developed in the early 1980s. It had a
label: paragraph

line: capacity of just over four billion IP addresses, all of which have been
label: paragraph

line: fully allocated to Internet service providers and users. An IPv4 address
label: paragraph

line: looks like this: 192.0.2.53.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Protocol version 6
label: paragraph

line: The next generation of Internet Protocol, with a 128-bit address space,
label: paragraph

line: which is 340 undecillion addresses. An IPv6 address looks like this:
label: paragraph

line: 2001:0db8::53. Where there are two colons side by side, all the seg-
label: paragraph

line: ments in between contain only zeros. So without the double colons,
label: paragraph

line: you would expand the example address to 2001:0db8:0000:0000:0000
label: paragraph

line: Inter-Registrar Transfer Policy
label: paragraph

line: The IRTP is a GNSO consensus policy that was adopted in 2004 with
label: paragraph

line: the objective to provide registrants with a transparent and predictable
label: paragraph

line: way to transfer domain name registrations between registrars.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Society
label: paragraph

line: The open international organization for global cooperation and
label: paragraph

line: coordination for the Internet and its internetworking technologies and
label: paragraph

line: applications.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Service Provider
label: paragraph

line: A company that provides access to the Internet to organizations and/
label: paragraph

line: or individuals. Access services provided by ISPs may include web host-
label: paragraph

line: ing, email, VoIP (voice over IP), and support for many other applica-
label: paragraph

line: tions.
label: paragraph

line: Internet Service Providers Constituency
label: paragraph

line: A constituency of the Generic Names Supporting Organization
label: paragraph

line: charged with the responsibility of advising the ICANN Board on policy
label: paragraph

line: issues relating to the management of the Domain Name System.
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: Post-expiration Domain Name Recovery
label: paragraph

line: The registrar practices regarding domain name expiration, renewal,
label: paragraph

line: transfer, deletion and post-expiration recovery.
label: paragraph

line: Fraudulent efforts to get information like usernames, passwords and
label: paragraph

line: credit card details by pretending to be a trustworthy entity in an email
label: paragraph

line: or instant message.

label: heading

label: paragraph

line: An Internet advertising model, used by Google AdWords and Bing
label: paragraph

line: among others, to direct traffic to specific websites, where advertisers
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: clicked.

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: on how to prevent potential abuses such as cybersquatting, front-
label: paragraph

line: running, fake renewal notices and more.

label: paragraph

line: A 30-day period offered by ICANN-accredited registrars for registrants

line: to restore a domain name that has expired or been deleted.

label: paragraph

line: on behalf of a registrant. Domain names ending with .aero, .biz, .com,
label: paragraph

line: .coop, .info, .museum, .name, .net, .org, and .pro can be registered
label: paragraph

line: through many different companies (known as “registrars”) that com-
label: paragraph

line: pete with one another. A listing of these companies appears in the
label: paragraph

label: paragraph

line: The authoritative, master database of all domain names registered
label: paragraph

line: REGISTRY
label: paragraph

line: in each top-level domain. The registry operator keeps the master
label: paragraph

line: database and also generates the “zone file” which allows computers to
label: paragraph

line: route Internet traffic to and from top-level domains anywhere in the
label: paragraph

line: world. Internet users don’t interact directly with the registry operator;
label: paragraph

line: users can register names in TLDs including .biz, .com, .info, .net, .name,
label: paragraph

line: .org by using an ICANN-Accredited Registrar.

label: paragraph

line: and RIPE NCC.

line: A memo published by the Internet Engineering Task Force describing
label: paragraph

line: innovations, research, behaviors or methods pertaining to how the In-
label: paragraph

line: Root Server System Advisory Committee
label: heading

line: An advisory committee to the ICANN Board about the operation of the
label: paragraph

line: root name servers of the Domain Name System.

line: Registries Stakeholder Group
label: paragraph

line: under contract with ICANN, in the Generic Names Supporting Organi-
label: paragraph

line: zation.

line: Structural Improvement Committee
label: paragraph

line: A committee of the ICANN Board of Directors responsible for review

line: An advisory committee to the ICANN Board, composed of volunteer
label: paragraph

line: members who are recognized experts in the domain name, address-
label: paragraph

line: ing, and/or security areas. All members provide independent advice
label: paragraph

line: and are expected to call attention to circumstances when the com-
label: paragraph

line: ments they offer are not their own.
label: paragraph

line: Supporting Organizations
label: paragraph

line: Three specialized advisory bodies that advise the ICANN Board of Di-
label: paragraph

line: rectors on issues relating to domain names (Generic Names Support-
label: paragraph

line: ing Organization and Country-Code Names Supporting Organization)
label: paragraph

line: and IP addresses (Address Supporting Organization).
label: paragraph

line: TLD Application System
label: paragraph

line: ICANN’s official online system for receiving and managing new gTLD
label: paragraph

line: applications.
label: paragraph

line: Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol
label: paragraph

line: A term used to refer to a suite of standard procedures and formats,
label: paragraph

line: sometimes called the Internet Protocol suite, which governs how
label: paragraph

line: computers communicate with each other over a network.
label: paragraph

line: T
label: heading

line: Top-level Domain
label: paragraph

line: TLD
label: heading

line: The names at the highest level of the Domain Name System hierarchy.
label: paragraph

line: For example, in the domain name www.example.com, the top-level
label: paragraph

line: domain is .com. There are different kinds of top-level domains, such
label: paragraph

line: as country code top-level domains (ccTLDs) like .de for Germany, and
label: paragraph

line: generic top-level domains (gTLDs) like .com or .org.
label: paragraph

line: U
label: heading

line: Uniform Dispute Resolution Policy
label: paragraph

line: UDRP
label: paragraph

line: A set of agreed-upon policies and procedures that define how to
label: paragraph

line: resolve domain name registration disputes, such as abusive
label: paragraph

line: registrations that harm existing brands or trademarks, with any
label: paragraph

line: ICANN-accredited registrars.
label: paragraph

line: Uniform Resource Locator
label: paragraph

line: URL
label: paragraph

line: The unique address or file path that points to the location of a file on
label: paragraph

line: the Internet. Every web site has a unique URL that can be entered into
label: paragraph

line: a browser to access and view it.
label: paragraph

line: Uniform Rapid Suspension
label: paragraph

line: URS
label: paragraph

line: A means for trademark owners to request a quick decision from a reg-
label: paragraph

line: istry to take down an infringing web site. The procedure only allows for
label: paragraph

line: suspension of the web site; it does not enable transfer of the infringing
label: paragraph

line: web site to the complainant.
label: paragraph

line: W
label: heading

line: World Wide Web Consortium
label: paragraph

line: W3C
label: paragraph

line: An international industry consortium that develops common
label: paragraph

line: protocols to promote the evolution of the World Wide Web and ensure
label: paragraph

line: its interoperability.
label: paragraph

line: World Intellectual Property Organization
label: paragraph

line: WIPO
label: paragraph

line: An intergovernmental organization responsible for the promotion
label: paragraph

line: of the protection of intellectual rights throughout the world. It is
label: paragraph

line: one of the 16 specialized agencies of the United Nations system of
label: paragraph

line: organizations.
label: paragraph

line: WHOIS
label: paragraph

line: WHOIS (pronounced “who is”; not an acronym) An Internet Protocol
label: paragraph

line: that is used to query databases to obtain information about the
label: paragraph

line: registration of a domain name or IP address. ICANN’s gTLD agree-
label: paragraph

line: ments require registries and registrars to offer an interactive web page
label: paragraph

line: and a port 43 WHOIS service providing free public access to data on
label: paragraph

line: registered names. Data includes the domain registration creation and
label: paragraph

line: expiration dates, name servers, and contact information for the regis-
label: paragraph

line: trant and designated administrative and technical contacts.
label: paragraph

line: Working Group
label: paragraph

line: WG
label: paragraph

line: A team of ICANN volunteers working on a specific topic or policy.
label: paragraph

line: ONE WORLD.
label: heading

line: About ICANN
label: heading

line: ONE INTERNET.
label: heading

line: ICANN’s mission is to ensure a stable and unified global Internet.
label: paragraph

line: To reach another person on the Internet you have to type an address into your computer—a name or a number. That address has
label: paragraph

line: to be unique so computers know where to find each other. ICANN coordinates these unique identifiers across the world. Without
label: paragraph

line: that coordination we wouldn’t have one global Internet.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN was formed in 1998. It is a not-for-profit public-benefit corporation with participants from around the world dedicated to keep-
label: paragraph

line: ing the Internet secure, stable and interoperable. It promotes competition and develops policy on the Internet’s unique identifiers.
label: paragraph

line: ICANN doesn’t control content on the Internet. It cannot stop spam and it doesn’t deal with access to the Internet. But through
label: paragraph

line: its coordination role of the Internet’s naming system, it does have an important impact on the expansion and evolution of the
label: paragraph

line: Internet. For more information please visit www.icann.org.
label: paragraph
